To the Tune of *Wang Jiangnan*

The elixir moves to the right,
In the fourth revolution, yin is cultivated.
The work of the fourth revolution nurtures inner yin,
The elixir rests in the right flank, signifying yin.

When the sixth day arrives, close the gate of yang qi—
The nose is the heavenly aperture, the passage of qi belonging to yang;
The mouth is the earthly aperture, the passage of qi belonging to yin.
On the nights of the third and sixth [days], seal the nose’s breath,
Cutting off its coming and going.
Thus yang qi descends within, filling the five viscera—
This is using yang to nourish yin.

The Jade Pass’s spring permeates, uniting *ding* and *ren*.
Sealing the nose’s breath, the Flowery Pond’s waters brim,
Trickling down the heart’s network.
Water and fire intermingle within;
Heart qi descends, kidney qi ascends,
*Ding* and *ren* unite to nurture the sacred embryo.

The turtle plays, rising and sinking at will—
When yin and yang’s measures are complete,
The embryo in the right flank,
Now ascending, now descending,
Sways with the qi’s movement,
Like a turtle in water, drifting and diving as it pleases.

At times, it comes and goes without hindrance,
Piercing others’ hearts—
When the sacred embryo’s spirit is sufficient,
Its comings and goings are unimpeded.
At dawn, it roams in the western lands;
At dusk, it enters the eastern capital.
Without leaving the chamber, one sits and surveys the realm.
As for the minds of others,
One’s spirit may commune with theirs,
Discerning their intentions—
This is called "piercing others’ hearts,"
The penetration of others’ minds.

Playful, the spirit’s constant emergence from the face—
When the sacred embryo is perfected,
The infant comes and goes between the brows,
Roaming and playing within the four seas,
Manifesting the natural wonder of spiritual power.

A halo of light encircles, spanning a thousand *xun*—
The inner elixir’s radiance envelops the body,
Its form like the moon.

Neither cold nor heat can encroach.

**Oral Instructions**
After the elixir enters the right flank,
Cultivate the work of the fourth revolution.
Whenever encountering the sixth, sixteenth, or twenty-sixth day of the month,
At midnight, the hour of *zi*,
After washing and rinsing,
Enter a quiet chamber.
Close the eyes, cross the legs,
Knock the teeth thirty-six times,
Gather the spirit, settle the qi,
And seal the nose’s breath.
Though the nose’s breath is sealed,
Do not force it as in previous days.
Let there be no breath of coming or going within the nose,
Perfectly still and unmoving.
Wait until true qi fills within,
The elixir’s qi pierces the tongue’s aperture,
The Flowery Pond’s fluids well up, filling the mouth,
Nearly overflowing—
Then gently swallow them, guiding them to the heart.
When the divine water reaches the heart,
It stirs the divine fire;
The five viscera grow warm,
The whole body sweats,
The four limbs relax—
This is one cycle.
On each of the third and sixth nights,
Perform this three times and then stop.
This is the time for divine water and divine fire
To bathe and nurture the sacred embryo.

After this,
Suddenly, in the midst of practice,
The inner elixir from the right flank
Rumbles like thunder,
A stream of hot qi flows into the elixir field.
Firelight shoots from the nose—
This is the inner elixir returning to the elixir field,
Completing the fifth revolution.
From this point onward,
No longer practice sealing the gate of yang breath.

**Song of the Fifth Revolution**
The fifth revolution completes the transformations of yin and yang—
The third revolution nurtures inner yang,
The fourth revolution nurtures inner yin.
By the fifth revolution, the measures of inner and outer yin and yang are complete,
The work of transformation is done,
The sacred embryo is nurtured,
And spiritual power is free.

The infant, a foot long, plays with solar essence—
After the fifth revolution,
The inner elixir’s sacred embryo,
Having nurtured its numinous body,
Grows over a foot in length.
From this point, one absorbs the sun’s essence
To nourish outer yang,
Seizing the transformative power of heaven and earth.

Waking, one roams the four seas; sleeping, one knows one’s place—
Ordinary people, lacking inner cultivation,
Scatter their spirit and essence,
With no place to return.
By day, their spirit dwells in the heart;
By night, their spirit leaves the body.
When they fall asleep,
Their spirit has no guard,
They forget their body,
And know not where they are.
Following the *hun* and chasing the *po*,
They enter dark realms,
Gathering with ghosts.
In dreams, they see all things.
When the four great elements suddenly dissolve,
Their spirit follows the ghosts,
Receiving rebirth according to their fortune.
Heaven and hell are not of their choosing—
This is because their spirit does not recognize its own body,
Drifting with the waves.

Those who attain the Dao,
Having perfected the inner elixir,
Dwell their spirit in the elixir,
Their numinous body free.
By day, their spirit roams;
By night, their spirit settles.
When they sleep,
Their spirit sees their body,
And no thing can tempt it.
Thus the *hun* and *po* lie hidden,
A hundred evils cannot intrude.
No more dreams or sleep—
They depart from life and death,
Coming and going as they please.
Their spirit’s comings and goings are unfathomable,
Thus the elixir classics say, "The true person has no dreams,"
Referring to this.

Coming and going, they wander effortlessly.

chunks.original_text: 珠自右，飞电入丹城， 四转功成，阴阳数足，内丹玄珠，忽自右胁，一道真火，飞入丹田。 其声如雷，鼻光如火，乃是丹珠内阴内阳皆足，复归丹田，以成五转之位也。 内养婴儿盈尺象， 圣胎之内，真人成就，出入顶门，长尺余也。 时逢九数采阳精。 三转养内阳，四转养内阴，故阴阳皆足，丹归丹田，功成五转，则夺天地造北，采日之精以养其外阳，修行之道，自内及外，其序顺也。 故自五转之后，於一月之内，逢三九之日，采日之精，以养圣胎矣！ 火向水中 生行持之法，以水求火，以阴感阳，水火既济，阴阳大和，故曰火向水中生也。 烧鬼岳，紫殿势峥嵘。 常人於丹田下积阴气，谓之鬼岳。 丹成五转，内外火发，烧尽鬼岳，遍体纯阳。 阴鬼山岳，焚烧，阳神宫殿建立，故曰烧山符子鬼难看也。 随意出游寰海内，寐如沙碛卧长鲸，时序与偕行。 五转之后，造化功成，与天地合德，日月齐明，变化与时流通，故曰与偕行也。 口诀 内丹复入丹田，五转之功成就，内之阴阳数足，当采外之阴阳，以成大道。 凡遇每月初九、十九、二十九、三九之日，当正午时，面南盘膝，闭目对日而坐，候气定，闭鼻息，使息无往来，真阳不漏，充满於内。 其内之真火与外之真火交通，自觉一身上下通红明满。 坐一二刻后，渐渐丹田真水一道，冷气上贯於心，如水晶一团，在其心上，然后开眼开息，从鼻中吸日之气，九九八十一口，纳之於心，其日气到心之后，与真水相激，吸气一半之后，渐觉心头气动，内丹在丹田，如鱼涌跃，乃是阴阳大和，至八十一口而止。 如此行持三年而毕，三载数足，不采日精，却采月华也。 六转歌 六转神全弄月华， 丹至六转，内外阴阳皆足，圣胎神全，其真人与内身一体，每遇月圆之夜，采月之英华，以积真阴，故曰弄月华。 变胎魂魄影潜赊， 变胎，谓凡胎成圣胎也。 五转真阳全，魂化为神； 六转真阴全，魄化为气。 魂魄内外，则日中游行，更无其影。 自此之后，鬼神不可见，而阴场不可测，以为真仙之道，影潜赊也。 阳砂换骨阴消肉， 人之凡胎浊骨，阴阳不洁，不能上升。 得道真人，丹成四转之后，至五转，采日精纳於丹田，结为阳砂。 采日一年之后，其阳砂内纯，入於髓中，换其凡骨，内生仙骨。 但觉夜间汗出如白膏，乃是凡骨随汗而消也，至八十一口而止。 如故曰阳砂换骨。 五转换骨之后，至六转，采月华纳於丹田，结为阴粉。 采月华一年之后，其阴粉内化入於肉中，换其凡肉，以养仙肌。 但觉大小便常有紫血随气换下，乃是几肉暗消，仙肌肉生，故曰阴消肉也。 换尽由如玉去瑕 玉之有瑕，不成真玉，人有凡肌浊骨，不成真人。 六转之后，换其几骨而生仙骨，去其凡肌而生仙肌，换尽无瑕，神明纯一也。 望江南 日精满，阴魄化无形， 六转阴阳数全，魂魄内化，形体无形，以登真人之道也。 每遇月圆开北户， 六转之后，每遇月圆十五夜，运北方肾水交南方心火，使内外水火既济，以结阴粉，与天地造化通流，以育圣胎也。 神龟时饮碧瑶泠。 神龟，肾水中龟也。 饮海龟儿人不识，乃是采月之英华纳於神水之府，其神龟饮之阴粉，也。 生於北海之中 形魄岂能停，

The pearl from the right,
A bolt of lightning enters the cinnabar city.
After four revolutions, the work is complete,
Yin and yang’s numbers fulfilled.
The inner elixir’s mystic pearl
Suddenly from the right flank—
A stream of true fire
Flies into the cinnabar field.
Its sound like thunder,
Its nose’s light like flame.
This is when the pearl’s inner yin and inner yang are both full,
Returning to the cinnabar field
To complete the fifth revolution’s position.

Within the sacred embryo, the infant grows a foot long,
The true person perfected within the holy womb,
Exiting and entering through the crown gate,
Over a foot in length.

At times, meeting the ninefold numbers, they gather yang essence.
The third revolution nurtures inner yang,
The fourth nurtures inner yin.
Thus yin and yang are both full,
The elixir returns to the cinnabar field,
The work of the fifth revolution complete—
They seize heaven and earth’s creative power,
Gathering the sun’s essence to nourish their outer yang.
The path of cultivation,
From inner to outer,
Follows this natural order.
Therefore, after the fifth revolution,
Within a month’s time,
On the days of the three nines,
They gather the sun’s essence
To nourish the sacred embryo.

Fire arises within water.
The method of practice:
Seeking fire through water,
Drawing yang through yin.
Water and fire in harmony,
Yin and yang in great accord—
Thus fire arises within water.

Burning the Ghost Mountain,
The purple palace stands towering.
Ordinary people accumulate yin qi below the cinnabar field,
Called the Ghost Mountain.
When the elixir completes the fifth revolution,
Inner and outer fire ignite,
Burning away the Ghost Mountain,
The entire body pure yang.
The yin ghost’s mountain consumed,
The yang spirit’s palace established—
Thus the mountain burns, and the ghost’s talisman is no more.

Wandering at will through the seas of the world,
Sleeping like a whale on the desert sands,
Moving in harmony with the seasons.
After the fifth revolution,
The work of creation is complete,
Joining virtue with heaven and earth,
Bright as the sun and moon.
Transformations flow with time—
Thus they move in harmony with it.

Oral Instructions:
When the inner elixir returns to the cinnabar field,
The work of the fifth revolution complete,
The numbers of inner yin and yang fulfilled,
Then gather outer yin and yang
To perfect the great Dao.
Whenever encountering the ninth, nineteenth, or twenty-ninth day of the month—
The three ninefold days—
At high noon,
Face south, cross your legs,
Close your eyes, and sit facing the sun.
Wait for the qi to settle,
Close your nostrils, and halt your breath,
So that true yang does not leak,
Filling the interior.
The inner true fire communicates with the outer true fire,
And you will feel your entire body above and below
Glowing red and radiant.
After sitting for one or two moments,
Gradually, a stream of true water from the cinnabar field,
A cold qi, rises to penetrate the heart,
Like a sphere of crystal
Resting above it.
Then open your eyes and release your breath,
Inhaling the sun’s qi through your nose,
Eighty-one breaths in all,
Drawing it into the heart.
Once the sun’s qi reaches the heart,
It clashes with the true water.
After half the breaths,
You will gradually feel the qi stir in your heart,
The inner elixir in the cinnabar field
Like a leaping fish—
This is the great harmony of yin and yang.
Stop at eighty-one breaths.
Practice this for three years to complete the work.
When the three-year count is full,
Cease gathering the sun’s essence
And instead gather the moon’s radiance.

The Sixth Revolution Song:
At the sixth revolution, the spirit is whole, playing with the moon’s radiance.
When the elixir reaches the sixth revolution,
Inner and outer yin and yang are both full,
The sacred embryo’s spirit complete.
The true person and the inner body become one.
On every full moon night,
They gather the moon’s essence and splendor
To accumulate true yin—
Thus they play with the moon’s radiance.

Transforming the embryo, the hun and po’s shadows recede.
Transforming the embryo:
The ordinary womb becomes the sacred womb.
At the fifth revolution, true yang is complete,
The hun transforms into spirit.
At the sixth revolution, true yin is complete,
The po transforms into qi.
With hun and po within and without,
They wander at noon without shadow.
From this point on,
Even ghosts and spirits cannot see them,
And the yin realm is unfathomable—
This is the true immortal’s path,
The shadow receding into obscurity.

Yang cinnabar replaces the bones, yin dissolves the flesh.

At noon, no shadow remains.
Yang sand glows crimson; yin powder bears a faint azure hue.
The essence of the sun coalesces—this is yang’s radiance;
The essence of the moon coalesces—this is yin’s splendor.
Its crimson hue mirrors the sun;
Its pale tint mirrors the moon.
Powder refines the flesh; sand transforms the bones.
The mortal embryo is wholly exchanged for the sacred embryo’s numinosity.
The hun merges with spirit; the po merges with qi.
In purity, they become one—
Form and spirit both wondrous,
In perfect unity with the Dao.

They ascend like shooting stars.
For those who cultivate the Dao,
If they preserve their spirit but fail to transform their form,
The body becomes a burden:
When the spirit departs, the body remains unmoved;
When the corpse dissolves, the form does not depart.
After six revolutions of the elixir,
The mortal form is entirely transmuted into immortal substance—
Form and spirit both wondrous.
Where the spirit directs, the form follows,
Rising through the nine heavens,
Swift as a star.

**Oral Instructions:**
When the elixir completes six revolutions,
Gather the moon’s radiance.
On every full moon’s fifteenth night,
At midnight’s zi hour,
Bathe and rinse, then sit facing the moon.
Close your eyes, cross your legs,
Regulate your breath through the nose,
And seal your mouth,
Cutting off the flow of breath through mouth and nose,
So that true qi does not leak outward.
Within, true qi fills the six viscera.
The true yin of the kidneys and the essence of the great yin
Are inwardly and outwardly absorbed,
And yin qi circulates freely.
You will feel your entire body gleam like crystal,
Limpid and luminous.
After a moment or two,
The true water of the kidneys stirs the fire of the heart.
A thread of fiery qi from the heart’s spirit
Descends into the cinnabar field,
Like a wheel of flame resting in a lapis lazuli dish.
Then gently open your eyes, release your breath,
And through your nose, facing the moon,
Draw in the moon’s qi,
Absorbing sixty-four breaths before stopping.
After half the breaths are taken,
The moon’s true yin excites the true fire in the cinnabar field.
Water and fire intermingle,
Like boiling water—
The four limbs sweat,
The hundred vessels relax and flow,
Until the sixty-fourth breath is complete.
Practice this for two years,
And the work will be accomplished,
Preparing you to enter the seventh revolution.

**Song of the Seventh Revolution:**
At seven revolutions, the body soars, weightless—
The immortal form, light and pure,
Naturally ascends.
The numinous light, breath sealed, fills the elixir’s city.
The inner elixir refines form and spirit,
So the entire body becomes the city that houses the elixir.
When the elixir reaches seven revolutions,
Inner and outer yin and yang harmonize.
One must seal the breath for a thousand mornings
To fulfill the wondrous Dao’s work.
After a thousand mornings of fasting, the spirit fire is born.
When the elixir completes seven revolutions,
And the breath is sealed for a thousand days,
Yin and yang achieve great harmony.
When the thousand days are fulfilled,
Spirit and qi unite,
The five viscera are renewed,
And inner and outer become pure and one.
The moon’s light shines through the six viscera;
True fire illuminates the five organs.
The worms in the viscera and stomach
Are transformed into water.
From this point, the intestines and stomach are full,
No longer taking in the food of smoke and fire.
Hunger is sated with immortal fruits;
Thirst is quenched with jade nectar.
The kun gate opens wide to bathe the sea whale.
After the inner elixir is wholly transformed,
The yin form dissolves entirely,
Leaving but one aperture—
Called the kun gate,
Symbolizing yin.
Whenever the divine elixir’s fire grows strong,
On the days of the three nines,
Enter the water,
Circulate the elixir pearl,
And let it emerge from the kun gate.
Breathe, play in the water,
And frolic freely.
After an hour or two,
Return the elixir to its chamber,
Nestling it in the elixir cave
To regulate the fire’s intensity.

**Looking Over the River South:**
The form penetrates the sun—
At seven revolutions, it soars at will.
After seven revolutions,
Form and spirit are both wondrous,
Inner organs and outer form
All become vessels of immortality.
Roaming at noon,
Form and shadow are luminous,
The hue like red jade.
Ascending and soaring through the void,
Moving freely as they please.
Secluded in deep cliffs, they sit in meditation,
Breath without coming or going—
Spirit congeals.
The work of the seventh revolution
Lies in harmonizing inner and outer,
So the radiance of the sun and moon without
Merges with the water and fire of heart and kidneys.
Yin and yang circulate,
Spirit and qi unite.
Secluded in mountain valleys,
They sit in meditation for a hundred days,
Sealing the breath through the nose
To cut off the flow of respiration.
Spirit and qi surge in harmony,
Congealing in great stillness.
The five viscera are inwardly full,
No longer consuming the world’s dust.
They realize the Dao of carefree wandering.
Fasting yields wonders,
Able to generate spirit fire,
Returning to the origin—qi pure and clear.
When the nine signs appear, bathe and open the earth gate.
Whenever the spirit fire grows excessive,
And the five viscera burn hot,
On the days of the nine,
Enter the water to bathe the true elixir.
It shines like a wheel of fire,
Emerging from the earth gate—
Thus the earth gate opens.
Drawing fire from the moon, seeking ice from the sun.
The moon symbolizes yin;
Spirit fire is the utmost yang.
The earth gate is yin’s aperture.
Guiding the yang light,
It emerges from the yin cavity of the earth gate—
Thus drawing fire from the moon.
The sun symbolizes yang;
Spirit water is the utmost yin.
The tongue’s aperture is yang’s cavity,
Through which spirit water flows,
Emerging from the yang cavity of the tongue—
Thus seeking ice from the sun.
The five organs are renewed.
At five revolutions, the bones are transformed;
At six, the flesh;
At seven, the five viscera.
The five organs are the five viscera—
Thus the five organs are renewed.

**Oral Instructions:**
When the elixir reaches seven revolutions,
One must leave the dusty world behind,
Entering deep mountains,
Sitting in meditation within cliffs.
Seal the breath, congeal the spirit,
Cutting off the flow of breath through mouth and nose,
So that true yin and true yang merge within the abdomen,
Seizing the creative power of heaven and earth,
Returning it to the four limbs.
After a thousand days,
The five viscera are wholly transformed,
And the fetal qi becomes immortal organs.
You will feel the aperture at the crown open,
Releasing red and black qi—
This is the dispersal of fetal qi.
When the thousand days are fulfilled,
The crown’s aperture closes—
The fetal qi is exhausted,
And the work of the seventh revolution is complete.

The elixir is the heart-pearl, and the heart resembles a monkey; bathing the elixir in spirit-water, the divine elixir floats and sinks within it—hence it is called *bathing the macaque*.

The spirit-water swallows the red turtle—
The elixir floats within the spirit-water, like a turtle swallowing water, describing its form.

When the elixir completes its eighth revolution, the Earth Belt is born within the navel. After closing the breath, the true water of the cinnabar field gradually waxes like the sun and moon. By the ninth day, the spirit-water rises to the Twelve-Storied Tower, and the cinnabar pearl is immersed within it, purging all fire-toxin. Thereafter, no sign of parched heat remains. The power of creation returns to the four limbs. After a thousand days, the five viscera are entirely transformed, and the fetal qi becomes the immortal viscera. At the eighth revolution, the Earth Belt hangs down to return to the origin,
Like an infant within the mother’s womb, enveloped in the fetal sac.
The stabilized qi cannot escape and suffers no loss—
For the infant’s navel holds the umbilical cord in its mouth,
The breath’s coming and going unceasing, this is natural womb-breath, hence no loss.
When the heart-elixir completes its eighth revolution,
A navel cord regenerates within the navel, resembling the infant’s form,
Restoring the Dao of the primordial origin—thus it is called *returning to the origin, the Earth Belt hangs down*.

Coursing through the womb-breath to nurture the infant—
The perfected one obtains the Earth Belt and circulates the qi of the celestial cycle, thus attaining longevity.
Whenever fire flares to scorch the elixir-cavern,
Plunge deep into the cool spring to play with the red turtle.
The red radiance is the cinnabar pearl; after the eighth revolution,
The inner refinement of true fire eliminates the affliction of heat-toxin.
Whenever fire flares, hold the Earth Belt in the mouth,
Seal the breath for nine days, and on the ninth day,
True water will surge from the cinnabar field like a gushing spring,
Rising to the Twelve-Storied Tower, the cinnabar pearl within the spirit-water,
Like a turtle sporting in the waves.
From this point onward, true fire holds no toxin,
And the affliction of elixir-heat vanishes—
Thus it is said: *plunge deep into the cool spring to play with the red turtle.*

**Looking Over the River South:**
Within and without, all is pervaded—
Only at the eighth revolution does one return to the origin.
